sn11.24:4.3: Now at that time two mendicants were overly attached,
sn11.24:4.4: and one of them transgressed against the other.
sn11.24:4.5: The transgressor confessed to the other mendicant,
sn11.24:4.7: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha,
sn11.24:4.8: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn11.24:4.9: and told him what had happened.
sn11.24:5.2: One who doesn’t recognize when they’ve made a mistake. And one who doesn’t properly accept the confession of someone who’s made a mistake.
sn11.24:5.4: There are two who are astute.
sn11.24:5.5: One who recognizes when they’ve made a mistake. And one who properly accepts the confession of someone who’s made a mistake.
sn11.24:5.6: These are the two who are astute.
sn11.24:6.1: Once upon a time, mendicants, Sakka, the Lord of Gods, guiding the gods of the Thirty-three, recited this verse:
